editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Acted by the Queen's majesty's servants, at the phoenix in drury-lane.
London, printed by Nicholas Okes for Richard Collins, and are to be sold at his shop in Paul's churchyard, at the sign of the three Kings. 1633.

div.head: To the truly noble, John, Earl of Peterborough, lord Mordant, baron of Turuey.
div.p:
Where a truth of merit hath a general warrant, there love is but a debt, acknowledgement a justice. Greatness cannot often claim virtue by inheritance; yet in this, yours appears most eminent, for that you are not more rightly heir to your fortunes, than glory shall be to your memory. Sweetness of disposition ennobles a freedom of birth; in both, your lawful interest adds honour to your own name, and mercy to my presumption. Your noble allowance of these first fruits of my leisure in the action, emboldens my confidence, of your as noble construction in this presentment: especially since my service must ever owe particular duty to your favours,
by a particular engagement. The gravity of the subject may easily excuse the lightness of the title: otherwise, I had been a severe judge against mine own guilt. Princes have vouchsafed grace to trifles, offered from a purity of devotion, your lordship may like wise please, to admit into your good opinion, with these weak endeavours, the constancy of affection from the sincere lover of your deserts in honour

div.head: To my friend the author.
div.l: With admiration I beheld this whore
Adorned with beauty, such as might restore
(If ever being as thy muse hath famed)
Her Giovanni, in his love unblamed:
The ready graces lent their willing aid,
Pallas herself now played the chambermaid
And helped to put her dressings on: secure
Rest thou, that thy name herein shall endure
To th'end of age; and Annabella be
Gloriously fair, even in her infamy.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Dispute no more in this, for know (Young man)
These are no school-points; nice philosophy
May tolerate unlikely arguments,
But heaven admits no jest; wits that presumed
On wit too much, by striving how to prove
There was no god; with foolish grounds of art,
Discovered first the nearest way to hell;
And filled the world with devilish atheism:
Such questions youth are fond; for better 'tis,
To bless the sun, than reason why it shines;
Yet he thou talkest of, is above the sun,
No more; I may not hear it.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Gentle father,
To you I have unclasped my burdened soul,
Emptied the store-house of my thoughts and heart,
Made myself poor of secrets; have not left
Another word untold, which hath not spoke
All what I ever durst, or think, or know;
And yet is here the comfort I shall have,
Must I not do, what all men else may, love?

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Yes. you may love fair son.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Must I not praise
That beauty, which if framed a new, the gods
Would make a god of, if they had it there;
And kneel to it, as I do kneel to them?

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Why foolish madman?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Shall a peevish sound,
A customary form, from man to man,
Of brother and of sister, be a bar
Twixt my perpetual happiness and me?
Say that we had one father, say one womb,
(Curse to my joys) gave both us life, and birth;
Are we not therefore each to other bound
So much the more by nature; by the the links
Of blood, of reason; nay if you will have't,
Even of religion, to be ever one,
One soul, one flesh, one love, one heart, one all?

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Have done unhappy youth, for thou art lost.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Shall then, (For that I am her brother born)
My joys be ever banished from her bed?
No father; in your eyes I see the change.
Of pity and compassion: from your age
As from a sacred oracle. distils
The life of counsel: tell me holy man,
What cure shall give me ease in these extremes.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Repentance (Son) and sorrow for this sin:
For thou hast moved a majesty above
With thy un-ranged (Almost) blasphemy.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: O do not speak of that (Dear confessor)

sp.speaker: Fry,
sp.l: Art thou (My son) that miracle of wit,
Who once within these three months wert esteemed
A wonder of thine age, throughout Bononia?
How did the university applaud
Thy government, behaviour, learning, speech,
Sweetness, and all that could make up a man?
I was proud of my tutelage, and chose
Rather to leave my books, then part with thee,
I did so: but the fruits of all my hopes
Are lost in thee, as thou art in thyself.
O Giovanni: hast thou left the schools
Of knowledge, to converse with lust and death?
(For death waits on thy lust) look through the world,
and thou shalt see a thousand faces shine
More glorious, than this idol thou adorest:
Leave her, and take thy choice, 'tis much less sin,
Though in such games as those, they lose that win.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: It were more ease to stop the ocean
From floats and ebbs, than to dissuade my vows.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Then I have done, and in thy wilful flame:
Already see thy ruin; heaven is just,
Yet hear my counsel.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: As a voice of life.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Hie to thy father's house, there lock thee fast
Alone within thy chamber, then fall down
On both thy knees, and grovel on the ground:
Cry to thy heart, wash every word thou utterest
In tears, (And if't be possible) of blood:
Beg heaven to cleanse the leprosy of lust
That rots thy soul, acknowledge what thou art,
A wretch, a worm, a nothing: weep, sigh, pray
Three times a day, and three times every night:
For seven days' space do this, then if thou findest
No change in thy desires, return to me:
I'll think on remedy, pray for thyself
At home, whilst I pray for thee here — away,
My blessing with thee, we have need to pray.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: All this I'll do, to free me from the rod
Of vengeance, else I'll swear, my fate's my god,

div.stage: Enter Grimaldi and Vasques ready to fight.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.l: Come sir, stand to your tackling, if you prove craven,
I'll make you run quickly.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Thou art no equal match for me.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.p: Indeed I never went to the wars to bring home news, nor cannot play the mountebank for a meal's meat, and swear I got my wounds in the field: see you these grey hairs, they'll not flinch for a bloody nose, wilt thou to this gear?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p:
Why slave, think'st thou I'll balance my reputation
with a cast-suit; call thy master, he shall know that I dare —

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.p: Scold like a cotquean (That's your profession) thou poor shadow of a soldier, I will make thee know, my master keeps servants, thy betters in quality and performance: com'st thou to fight or prate?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Neither with thee,
I am a Roman. and a gentleman, one that have got
Mine honour with expense of blood,

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.l: You are a lying coward, and a fool, fight, or by these hilts
I'll kill thee — brave my lord, — you'll fight.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Provoke me not, for if thou dost —

div.stage: They fight, Grimal. hath the worst

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.l: Have you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What meaned these sudden broils so near my doors?
Have you not other places, but my house
To vent the spleen of your disordered bloods?
Must I be haunted still with such unrest,
As not to eat, or sleep in peace at home?
Is this your love Grimaldi? Fie, 'tis naught.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: And Vasques. I may tell thee 'tis not well
To broach these quarrels, you are ever forward
In seconding contentions.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What's the ground?

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: That with your patience signiore, I'll resolve
This gentleman, whom fame reports a soldier,
(For else I know not) rivals me in love
To signior Florio's daughter; to whose ears
He still prefers his suit to my disgrace,
Thinking the way to recommend himself,
Is to disparage me in his report:
But know Grimaldi, though (May be) thou art
My equal in thy blood, yet this betrays
A lowness in thy mind; which were't thou noble
Thou would it as much disdain, as I do thee
For this unworthiness; and on this ground
I willed my servant to correct this tongue,
holding a man, so base, no match for me.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.p: And had your sudden coming prevented us, I had let my gentleman blood under the gills; I should have wormed you sir, for running mad.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: I'll be revenged Soranzo.

sp.speaker: Vas
sp.p: On a dish of warm-broth to stay your stomach, do honest innocence, do; spoon-meat is a wholesomer diet than a Spanish blade.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Remember this.

sp.speaker: Sor.
sp.l: I fear thee not Grimaldi.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My lord Soranzo, this is strange to me,
Why you should storm, having my word engaged:
Owing her heart, what need you doubt her ●are?
Losers' may talk by law of any game.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.l: Yet the villain of words, signior Florio may be such,
As would make any unspleened dove, choleric,
Blame not my lord in this.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Be you more silent,
I would not for my wealth, my daughter's love
Should cause the spilling of one drop of blood.
Vasques put up, let's end this fray in wine.

sp.speaker: Putana
sp.p: How like you this child? here's threatening challenging, quarrelling, and fighting, on every side, and all is for your sake; you had need look to yourself (Charge) you'll be stolen away sleeping else shortly.

sp.speaker: Annabella:
sp.l: But (Tutoress) such a life, gives no content
To me, my thoughts are fixed on other ends;
Would you would leave me.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Leave you? no marvel else; leave me, no leaving (Charge)
This is love outright, indeed I blame you not, you have
Choice fit for the best lady in Italy.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Pray do not talk so much.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p:
Take the worst with the best, there's Grimaldi the soldier a very well-timbered fellow: they say he is a roman, nephew to the Duke mount Ferratto, they say he did good service in the wars against the millanoys, but faith (Charge) I do not like him, and be for nothing, but for being a soldier; one amongst
twenty of your skirmishing captains, but have some privy may me or other, that mars their standing upright, I like him the worse, he crinkles so much in the hams; though he might serve, if their were no more men, yet he's not the man I would choose.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Fie how thou pratest.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: As I am a very woman, I like signior Soranzo, well; he is wise, and what is more, rich; and what is more than that, kind, and what is more than all this, a nobleman; such a one were I the fair Annabella, myself, I would wish and pray for: than he is bountiful; beside he is handsome, and, by my troth, I think wholesome: (And that's news in a gallant of three and twenty. ) liberal that I know: loving, that you know; and a man sure, else he could never ha' purchased such a good name, with Hippolita the lusty widow in her husband's life time: and 'twere but for that report (Sweet heart) would'a were thine: commend a man for his qualities, but take a husband as he is a plain-sufficient, naked man: such a one is for your bed, and such a one is signior Soranzo my life for't.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Sure the woman took her morning's draught to soon.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: But look (Sweet heart,) look what thing comes now:
Here's another of your ciphers to fill up the number:
O brave old ape in a silken coat, observe.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Didst thou think Poggio, that I would spoil my
New clothes, and leave my dinner to fight.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: No sir, I did not take you for so arrant a baby.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am wiser than so: for I hope Poggio. thou
Never heardest of an elder brother, that was a coxcomb,
Didst Poggio?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Never indeed sir, as long as they had either land or money left them to inherit .

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Is it possible Poggio? o monstruous! why I'll undertake, with a handful of silver, to buy a headful of wit at any time, but sirrah, I have another purchase in hand, I shall have the wench mine uncle says, I will but wash my face, and shift socks, and then have at her i'faith —
mark my pace Poggio.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Sir I have seen an. Ass, and a mule trot the Spanish pavin with a better grace, I know not how often.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: This idiot haunts me too.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Ay, ay, he needs no description, the rich magnifico, that is below with your father (Charge) signior Donado his uncle; for that he means to make this his cousin a golden calf, thinks that you will be a right Israelite, and fall down to him presently: but I hope I have tutored you better: they say a fool's babble is a lady's play fellow: yet you having wealth enough, you need not cast upon the dearth of flesh at any rate: hang him innocent.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: But see Putana, see: what blessed shape
Of some celestial creature now appears?
What man is he, that with such sad aspect
Walks careless of himself?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Where

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Look below.

sp.speaker: Put,
sp.l: O, 'tis your brother sweet —

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: 'Tis your brother.

sp.speaker: Anna,
sp.l: Sure 'tis not he, this is some woeful thing
Wrapped up in grief, some shadow of a man.
Alas he beats his breast, and wipes his eyes
Drowned all in tears: methinks I hear him sigh.
Lets down Putana? and partake the cause,
I know my brother in the love he bears me,
Will not deny me partage in his sadness,
My soul is full of heaviness and fear.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Lost, I am lost: my fates have doomed my death:
The more I strive, I love, the more I love,
The less I hope: I see my ruin, certain.
What judgement, or endeavours could apply
To my incurable and restless wounds,
I thoroughly have examined, but in vain:
Oh that it were not in religion sin,
to make our love a god, and worship it.
I have even wearied heaven with prayers, dried up
The spring of my continual tears, even starved
My veins with daily fasts: what wit or art
Could counsel, I have practised; but alas
I find all these but dreams, and old men's tales
To fright unsteady youth; I'm still the same,
Or I must speak, or burst; 'tis not I know,
My lust; but 'tis my fare that leads me on.
Keep fear and low faint hearted shame with slaves,
I'll tell her, that I love her, though my heart
Were rated at the price of that attempt.
O me! she comes.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: If such a thing
As courage dwell in men, (Ye heavenly powers)
Now double all that virtue in my tongue.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Why brother, will you not speak to me?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Yes; how d'ye sister?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Howsoever I am, methinks you are not well.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Bless us why are you so sad sir.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Let me entreat you leave us a while, Putana,
Sister, I would be private with you.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Withdraw Putana.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: I will, if this were any other company for her, I should think my absence an office of some credit; but I will leave them together.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Come sister lend your hand, let's walk together.
I hope you need not blush to walk with me,
Here's none but you and I.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Faith I mean no harm.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Harm?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: No good faith; how is't wi'thee?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: I trust he be not frantic
I am very well brother.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Trust me but I am sick, I fear so sick,
'Twill cost my life.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Mercy forbid it: 'tis not so I hope.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I think you love me sister.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Yes you know, I do.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I know't indeed — you're very fair.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Nay then I see you have a merry sickness,

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: That's as it proves: they poets feign (I read)
That Juno for her forehead did exceed
All other goddesses: but I durst swear,
Your forehead exceeds hers, as hers did theirs.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Troth this is pretty.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Such a pair of stars.
As are thine eyes, would (Like Promethean fire.)
(If gently glanced) give life to senseless stones.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Fie upon'ee,

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: The lily and the rose most sweetly straying
Upon your dimpled cheeks do strive for change.
Such lips would tempt a saint; such hands as those
Would make an anchoret lascivious.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: D'ye mock me ', or flatter me,

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: If you would see a beauty more exact
Than art can counter fit, or nature frame,
Look in your glass, and there behold your own.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: O you are a trim youth.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: What to do.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: And here's my breast, strike home.
Rip up my bosom, there thou shalt behold
A heart, in which is writ the truth I speak.
Why stand 'ee?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Are you earnest?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Yes most earnest.
You cannot love?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Whom.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Me, my tortured soul
Hath felt affliction in the heat of death.
O Annabella I am quite undone,
the love of thee (My sister) and the view
Of thy immortal beauty hath untuned
All harmony both of my rest and life,
Why d'ye not strike?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Forbid it my just fears,
If this be true, 'twere fitter I were dead.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: True Annabella; 'tis no time to jest,
I have too long suppressed the hidden flames
That almost have consumed me; I have spent
Many a silent night in sighs and groans,
Ran over all my thoughts, despised my fate,
Reasoned against the reasons of my love,
Done all that smooth-cheeked virtue could advise,
But found all bootless; 'tis my destiny,
That you must either love, or I must die.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Comes this in sadness from you?

sp.speaker: Gio,
sp.l: Let some mischief
Befall me soon, if I dissemble ought.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: You are my brother Giovanni.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: You,
My sister Annabella; I know this:
And could afford you instance why to love
So much the more for this; to which intent
Wise nature first in your creation meant
To make you mine: else't had been sin and foul,
To share one beauty to a double soul.
Nearness in birth or blood, doth but persuade
A nearer nearness in affection.
I have asked counsel of the holy church,
Who tells me I may love you, and 'tis just,
That since I may, I should; and will, yes will:
Must I now live, or die?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Live, thou hast won
The field, and never fought; what thou hast urged,
My captive heart had long ago resolved.
I blush to tell thee, (But I'll tell thee now)
For every sigh that thou hast spent for me,
I have sighed ten; for every tear shed twenty:
And not so much for that I loved, as that
I durst not say I loved; nor scarcely think it.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Let not this music be a dream (Ye gods)
For pity-sake I beg 'ee.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: On my knees,
Brother, even by our mother's dust, I charge you,
Do not betray me to your mirth or hate,
Love me, or kill me brother.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: On my knees,
Sister, even by my mother's dust I charge you,
Do not betray me to your mirth or hate,
Love me, or kill me sister.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: You mean good sooth then?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: In good troth I do,
And so do you I hope: say, I'm in earnest:

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: I'll swear't and I.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: And I, and by this kiss,
(Once more, yet once more, now let's rise, by this)
I would not change this minute for Elysium,
What must we now do?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: What you will.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Come then,
After so many tears as we have wept,
Let's learn to court in smiles, to kiss and sleep.

sp.speaker: Elo.
sp.l: Signior Donado, you have said enough,
I understand you, but would have you know,
I will not force my daughter 'gainst her will.
You see I have but two, a son and her;
And he is so devoted to his book,
As I must tell you true, I doubt his health:
Should he miscarry, all my hopes rely
Upon my girl; as for worldly fortune,
I am I thank my stars, blessed with enough:
My care is how to match her to her liking,
I would not have her marry wealth, but love,
And if she like your nephew, let him have her,
here's all that I can say.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Sir you say well,
Like a true father, and for my part, I
If the young folks can like, (Twixt you and me )
Will promise to assure my nephew presently,
Three thousand florins yearly during life,
And after I am dead, my whole estate.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis a fair proffer sir, mean time your nephew
Shall have free passage to commence his suit;
If he can thrive, he shall have my consent,
So for this time I'll leave you signior.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Well,
Here's hope yet, if my nephew would have wit,
But he is such another dunce, I fear
He'll never win the wench; when I was young
I could have done't i'faith, and so shall he
If he will learn of me; and in good time
He comes himself.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: How now Bergetto, whether away so fast?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: O uncle, I have heard the strangest news that ever came out of the mint, have I not Poggio.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Yes indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: What news Bergetto?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Why look ye uncle? my barber told me just now that there is a fellow come to town, who undertakes to make a mill go without the mortal help of any water or wind, only with sandbags: and this fellow hath a strange horse, a most excellent beast, I'll assure you uncle, (My barber says) whose head to the wonder of all Christian people, stands just behind where his tail is, is't nor true Poggio?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: So the barber swore for sooth.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: And you are running hither?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I forsooth uncle.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Wilt thou be a fool still? come sir, you shall not go, you have more mind of a puppet-play, then on the business I told ye: why thou great baby, wilt never have wit, wilt make thyself a may-game to all the world?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Answer for yourself master.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Why uncle, should I sit at home still, and not go abroad to see fashions like other gallants?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: To see hobby-horses: what wise talk I pray had you with Annabella, when you were at signior Florio's house?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: O the wench: uds sa' me, uncle; I tickled her with a rare speech, that I made her almost burst her belly with laughing.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Nay I think so, and what speech was't?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What did I say Poggio?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: For sooth my master said, that he loved her almost as well as he loved Parmasent, and swore (I'll be sworn for him). that she wanted but such a nose as his was, to be as pretty a young woman, as any was in Parma.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: O gross!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Nay uncle, then she asked me, whether my father had any more children than myself: and I said no, 'twere better he should have had his brains knocked out first.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: This is intolerable.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Then said she, will signior Donado your uncle leave you all his wealth?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Ha! that was good, did she harp upon that string?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Did she harp upon that string, I that she did: I answered, leave me all his wealth? why woman, he hath no other wit, if he had, he should hear on't to his ever lasting glory and confusion: I know (Quoth I) I am his white boy, and will not be gulled: and with that she fell into a great smile, and went away. Nay I did fit her.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Ah sirrah, then I see there is no changing of nature,
Well Bergetto, I fear thou wilt be a very ass still.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I should be sorry for that uncle.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Come, come you home with me, since you are no better a speaker, I'll have you write to her after some courtly manner, and enclose some rich jewel in the letter.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I marry, that will be excellent.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Peace innocent,
Once in my time I'll set my wits to school,
If all fail, 'tis but the fortune of a fool.

sp.speaker: Be●.
sp.l: Poggio, 'twill do Poggio.

div.head: Actus secundus.
div.stage: Enter Giovanni and Annabella, as from their chamber.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Come Annabella, no more sister now,
But love; a name more gracious, do not blush,
(Beauties sweet wonder) but be proud, to know
That yielding thou hast conquered, and inflamed
A heart whose tribute is thy brother's life.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: And mine is his, o how these stolen contents
Would print a modest crimson on my cheeks,
Had any but my heart's delight prevailed.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I marvel why the chaster of your sex
Should think this pretty toy called maidenhead,
So strange a loss, when being lost, 'tis nothing,
And you are still the same.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: 'Tis well for you,
Now you can talk.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Music as well consists
In th'ear, as in the playing.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: O you're wanton,
Tell on't, you're best, do.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Thou wilt chide me then,
Kiss me, so; thus hung Jove on Laeda's neck,
And sucked divine ambrosia from her lips:
I envy not the mightiest man alive,
But hold myself in being King of thee,
More great, then were I King of all the world:
But I shall lose you sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: But you shall not.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: You must be married mistress.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Yes, to whom?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Some one must have you.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: You must.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Nay some other.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Now prithee do not speak so, without jesting
You'll make me weep in earnest.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: What you will not.
But tell me sweet, canst thou be dared to swear
That thou wilt live to me, and to no other?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: By both our loves I dare, for didst thou know
My Giovanni, how all suitors seem
To my eyes hateful, thou wouldst trust me then.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Enough, I take thy word; sweet we must part,
Remember what thou vowest, keep well my heart.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Will you begone?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I must.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: When to return?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Soon.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Look you do.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Go where thou wilt, in mind I'll keep thee here,
And where thou art, I know I shall be there
Guardian.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Child, how is't child? well, thank heaven, hall

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: O guardian, what a paradise of joy
Have I passed over!

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Nay what a paradise of joy have you passed under? why now I commend thee (Charge) fear nothing, (Sweetheart) what though he be your brother; your brother's a man I hope, and I say still, if a young wench feel the fit upon her, let her take anybody , father or brother, all is one.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: I would not have it known for all the world.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Nor I indeed, for the speech of the people; else 'twere nothing.

sp.speaker: Florio within —
sp.p: Daughter Annabella.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: O me! my father, — here sir, — reach my work.

sp.speaker: Flo. within.
sp.p: What are you doing?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: So, let him come now,

div.stage: Enter Florio, Richardetto, like a doctor of physic, and Philotis with a lute in her hand.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: So hard at work, that's well; you lose no time, look, I have brought you company, here's one, a learned doctor, lately come from Padua, much skilled in physic, and for that I see you have of late been sickly, I entreated this reverent man to visit you some time.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: You're very welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: I thank you mistress,
Loud fame in large report hath spoke your praise,
As well for virtue as perfection:
For which I have been bold to bring with me
A kinswoman of mine, a maid, for song,
And music, one perhaps will give content,
please you to know her.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: They are parts I love,
And she for them most welcome.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Thank you lady.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Sir now you know my house, pray make not strange,
And if you find my daughter need your art,
I'll be your paymaster.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Sir, what I am she shall command.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You shall bind me to you,
Daughter, I must have conference with you,
About some matters that concerns us both.
Good master doctor, please you but walk in,
We'll crave a little of your cozens cunning:
I think my girl hath not quite forgotten
To touch an instrument, she could have don't,
We'll hear them both.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I'll wait upon you sir.
sp.stage: Enter Soranzo in his study reading a book.
sp.l: Love's measure is extreme, the comfort, pain:
The life unrest, and the reward disdain
What's here? look o'er again, 'tis so, so writes
This smooth licentious poet in his rhymes.
But Sanazar thou liest, for had thy bosom
Felt such oppression as is laid on mine,
Thou wouldst have kissed the rod that made the smart.
To work then happy muse, and contradict
What Sanazer hath in his envy writ.
Love's measure is the mean, sweet his annoys,
His pleasure's life, and his reward all joys.
Had Annabella lived when Sanazar
Did in his brief encomium celebrate
Venice that Queen of cities, he had left
That verse which gained him such a sum of gold,
And for one only look from Annabell
Had writ of her, and her diviner cheeks,
Oh how my thoughts are —

sp.speaker: Vasques within —
sp.p: Pray forbear, in rules of civility, lot me give notice on't: I shall be taxed of my neglect of duty and service.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: What rude intrusion interrupts my peace,
Can I be nowhere private?

sp.speaker: Vas. within.
sp.l: Troth you wrong your modesty.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: What's the matter Vasques, who is't?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: 'Tis I:
Do you know me now? look perjured man on her
Whom thou and thy distracted lust have wronged,
Thy sensual rage of blood hath made my youth
Ascorn to men and angels, and shall I
Be now a foil to thy unsated change?
Thou knowest (False wanton) when my modest fame
Stood free from stain, or scandal, all the charms
Of hell or sorcery could not prevail
Against the honour of my chaster bosom:
Thine eyes did plead in tears, thy tongue in oaths
Such and so many, that a heart of steel
Would have been wrought to pity, as was mine:
And shall the conquest of my lawful bed,
My husband's death urged on by his disgrace,
My loss of womanhood be ill rewarded
With hatred and contempt? No, know Soranzo,
I have a spirit doth as much distaste
The slavery of fearing thee, as thou
Dost loathe the memory of what hath passed.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: Nay dear Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Call me not dear,
Nor think with supple words to smooth the grossness
Of my abuses; 'tis not your new mistress,
Your goodly madam merchant shall triumph
On my dejection; tell her thus from me,
My birth was nobler, and by much more free.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: You are too violent.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You are too double
In your dissimulation, seest thou this,
This habit, these black mourning weeds of care,
'Tis thou art cause of this, and hast divorced
my husband from his life and me from him,
And made me widow in my widowhood.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: Will you yet hear?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: More of the perjuries?
Thy soul is drowned too deeply in those sins,
Thou needest not add to'th number.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: Then I'll leave you,
You are passed all rules of sense.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And thou of grace.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.p: Fie mistress, you, are not near the limits of reason, if my lord had a resolution as noble as virtue itself, you take the course to unedge it all. Sir I beseech you do not perplex her, griefs (Alas) will have a vent, I dare undertake madam Hippolita will now freely hear you.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: Talk to a woman frantic, are these the fruits of your love?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: They are the fruits of thy untruth, false man,
Didst thou not swear, whilst no happiness on earth
More than to call me wife? didst thou not vow
When he should die to marry me? for which
The devil in my blood, and thy protests
Caused me to counsel him to undertake
A voyage to Leghorn, for that we heard,
His brother there was dead, and left a daughter
Young and unfriended, who with much ado
I wished him to bring hither; he did so,
And went; and as thou knowest died on the way.
Unhappy man to buy his death so dear
With my advice; yet thou for whom I did it,
Forgettest thy vows, and leavest me to my shame.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: Who could help this?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Who? perjured man thou couldst,
If thou hadst faith or love.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: You are deceived,
The vows I made, (If you remember well)
Were wicked and unlawful, 'twere more sin
To keep them, than to break them; as for me
I cannot mask my penitence, think thou
How much thou hast digressed from honest shame,
In bringing of a gentleman to death
Who was thy husband, such a one as he,
So noble in his quality, condition,
Learning, behaviour, entertainment, love,
As Parma could not show a braver man.

sp.speaker: Vas,
sp.l: You do not well, this was not your promise.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: I care not, let her know her monstrous life,
Ere I'll be servile to so black a sin,
I'll be a curse; woman, come here no more,
Learn to repent and die; for by my honour
I hate thee and thy lust; you have been too foul.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.l: This part has been scurvily played.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: How foolishly this beast contemns his fate,
And shuns the use of that, which I more scorn
Than I once loved his love; but let him go,
My vengeance shall give comfort to his woe.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.l: Mistress, mistress madam Hippolita,
Pray a word or two.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: With me sir?

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.l: With you if you please.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.p: I know you are infinitely moved now, and you think you have cause, some I confess you have, but sure not so much as you imagine.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Indeed.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.p: O you were miserably bitter, which you followed even to the last syllable: faith you were somewhat too shrewd, by my life you could not have taken my lord in a worse time, since I first knew him: tomorrow you shall find him a new man.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Well, I shall wait his leisure.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.p: Fie, this is not a hearty patience, it comes sourly from you, troth let me persuade you for once.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I have it and it shall be so; thanks opportunity
— persuade me to what —

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.p: Visit him in some milder temper, oh if you could but master a little your female spleen, how might you win him!

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p:
He will never love me: Vasques, thou hast been a too trusty servant to such a master, and I believe thy reward in the end will fall
out like mine.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.p: So perhaps too.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Resolve thyself it will; had I one so true, so truly honest, so secret to my counsels, as thou hast been to him and his, I should think it a flight acquittance, not only to make him master of all I have, but even of myself.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.p: O you are a noble gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Wilt thou feed always upon hopes? well, I know thou art wise, and seest the reward of an old servant dally what it is

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.p: Beggary and neglect.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: True, but Vasques, were't thou mine, and wouldst be private to me and my designs; I here protest myself, and all what I can else call mine, should be at thy dispose.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.p: Work you that way old mole? than I have the wind of you — I were not worthy of it, by any desert that could lie — within my compass; if I could —

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.p: I should then hope to live in these my old years with rest and security.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Give me thy hand, now promise but thy silence,
And help to bring to pass a plot I have;
And here in sight of heaven, (That being done)
I make thee lord of me and mine estate.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.l: Come you are merry,
This is such a happiness that I can
Neither think or believe.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Promise thy secrecy, and 'tis confirmed.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.p: Then here I call our good genij foe-witnesses, whatsoever your designs are, or against whomsoever, I will not only be a special actor therein, but never disclose it till it be effected.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I take thy word, and with that, thee for mine:
Come then, let's more confer of this anon.
On this delicious bane my thoughts shall banquet,
Revenge shall sweeten what my griefs have tasted.

sp.speaker: Richar.
sp.l: Thou seest (My lovely niece) these strange mishaps,
How all my fortunes turn to my disgrace,
Wherein I am but as a looker on,
whiles others act my shame, and I am silent.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: But uncle, wherein can this borrowed shape
Give you content?

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: I'll tell thee gentle niece,
Thy wanton aunt in her lascivious riots
Lives now secure, thinks I am surely dead
In my late journey to Leghorn for you;
(As I have caused it to be rumoured out)
Now would I see with what an impudence
She gives scope to her loose adultery,
And how the common voice allows hereof:
Thus far I have prevailed.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Alas, I fear
You mean some strange revenge.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: O be not troubled,
Your ignorance shall plead for you in all,
But to our business, what, you learned for certain
How signior Florio means to give his daughter
In marriage to Soranzo?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Yes for certain.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: But how find you young Annabella's love,
Inclined to him?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: For ought I could perceive,
She neither fancies him or any else.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: There's mystery in that which time must show,
She used you kindly.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: And craved your company?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Often.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: 'Tis well, it goes as I could wish,
I am the doctor now, and as for you,
None knows you; if all fail not we shall thrive.
But who comes here?
I know him, 'tis Grimaldi,
A roman and a soldier, near allied
Unto the Duke of Montferrato, one
Attending on the nuntio of the Pope
That now resides in Parma, by which means
He hopes to get the love of Annabella,

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Save you sir.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: And you sir.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: I have heard
Of your approved skill, which through the city
Is freely talked of, and would crave your aid.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: For what sir?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Marry sir for this —
But I would speak in private.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Leave us cousin.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: I love fair Annabella, and would know
Whether in arts there may not be receipts
To move affection.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Sir perhaps there may,
But these will nothing profit you.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Not me?

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Unless I be mistaken, you are a man
Greatly in favour with the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: What of that?

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: In duty to his grace,
I will be bold to tell you, if you seek
To marry Florio's daughter, you must first
Remove a bar twixt you and her.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Richard:
sp.l: Soranzo is the man that hath her heart,
And while he lives, be sure you cannot speed.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Soranzo, what mine enemy, is't he?

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Is he your enemy?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: The man I hate,
Worse than confusion:
I'll tell him straight.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Nay, then take mine advice,
(Even for his grace's sake the Cardinal)
I'll find a time when he and she do meet,
Of which I'll give you notice, and to be sure
He shall not scape you, I'll provide a poison
To dip your rapier's point in, if he had
As many heads as (Hydra had, he dies.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: But shall I trust thee doctor?

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: As yourself,
Doubt not in ought; thus shall the fates decree,
By me Soranzo falls, that mined me.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Well sir, I must be content to be both your secretary and your messenger myself; I cannot tell what this letter may work, but as sure as I am alive, if thou come o'er to talk with her, I fear thou wilt mar whatsoever I make.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: You make uncle? why am not I big enough to carry mine own letter I pray?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Ay, I carry a fool's head o'thy own; why thou dunce, wouldst thou write a letter, and carry it thyself

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Yes that I would, and read it to her with my own mouth, for you must think, if she will not believe me myself when she hears me speak; she will not believe another's hand-writing. O you think I am a blockhead uncle, no sir, Poggio knows I have indited a letter myself, so I have.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Yes truly sir, I have it in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: A sweat one no doubt, pray let's see't.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I cannot read my own hand very well Poggio, read it Poggio.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Begin.

body.p: I could call you fair, and lie as fast as any that loves you, but my uncle being the older man, I leave it to him, as more fit for his age, and the colour of his beard: I am wise enough to tell you I can board where I see occasion, or if you like my uncle's wit better than mine, you shall marry me; if you like mine better than his , i will marry you in spite of your teeth; so commending my best parts to you, I rest.

closer.signed: Yours onwards and downwards, or you may choose, Bergetto.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Ah ha, here's stuff uncle.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Here's stuff indeed to shame us all,
Pray whose advice did you take in this learned letter?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: None upon my word, but mine own.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: And mine uncle, believe it, nobody's else; 'twas mine own brain, I thank a good wit for't.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Get you home sir, and look yond keep within doors till I return.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: How? that were a jest indeed; I scorn it i'faith.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: What you do not?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Judge me, but I do now.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Indeed sir 'tis very unhealthy.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Well sir, if I hear any of your apish running to motions, and fopperies till I come back, you were as good no; look to't.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Poggio, shall's steal to see this horse with the head in's tail?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: I but you must take heeds of whipping.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Dost take me for a child Poggio,
Come honest Poggio,

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Peace, thou hast told a tale, whose every word
Threatens eternal slaughter to the soul:
I'm sorry I have heard it; would mine ears
Had been one minute deaf, before the hour
That thou cam'st to me: oh young man castaway,
By the religious number of mine order,
I day and might have woken my aged eyes,
Above thy strength, to weep on thy behalf:
But heaven is angry, and be thou resolved,
Thou art a man remarked to taste a mischief,
Look for't; though it come late, it will come sure.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Father, in this you are uncharitable;
What I have done, I'll prove both fit and good.
It is a principal (Which you have taught
When I was yet your scholar) that the fame
And composition of the mind doth follow
The frame and composition of body:
So where the body's furniture is beauty,
The minds must needs be virtue: which allowed.
Virtue itself is reason but refined,
And love the quintessence of that, this proves
my sister's beauty being rarely fair,
Is rarely virtuous; chiefly in her love,
And chiefly in that love, her love to me.
If hers to me, then so is mine to her;
Since in like causes are effects alike.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: O ignorance in knowledge, long ago,
How often have I warned thee this before?
Indeed if we were sure there were no deity,
Nor heaven nor hell, than to be led alone,
By nature's light (As were philosophers
Of elder times) might instance some defence.
But 'tis not so; then madman, thou wilt find,
That nature is in heavens positions blind.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Your age o'er rules you, had you youth like mine,
You'd make her love your heaven, and her divine.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Nay then I see thou'rt too far sold to hell,
It lies not in the compass of my prayers
To call thee back; yet let me counsel thee:
Persuade thy sister to some marriage.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Marriage? why that's to damn her; that's to prove
Her greedy of variety of lust.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: O fearful! if thou wilt not, give me leave
To shrive her; lest she should die unabsolved.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: At your best leisure father, then she'll tell you,
How dear she doth prize my matchless love,
Than you will know what pity 'twere we two
Should have been sundered from each others arms.
View well her face, and in that little round,
You may observe a world of variety;
For colour, lips, for sweet perfumes, her breath;
For jewels, eyes; for threads of purest gold,
Hair; for delicious choice of flowers, cheeks;
Wonder in every portion of that throne:
Hear her but speak, and you will swear the spheres
Make music to the citizens in heaven:
But father, what is else for pleasure framed,
Lest I offend your ears shall go unnamed.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: The more I hear, I pity thee the more,
That one so excellent should give those parts:
All to a second death; what I can do
Is but to pray; and yet I could advise thee,
Wouldst thou be ruled.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: In what?

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Why leave her yet,
The throne of mercy is above your trespass,
Yet time is left you both —

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: To embrace each other,
Else let all time be struck quite out of number;
She is like me, and I like her resolved.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: No more, I'll visit her; this grieves me most,
Things being thus, a pair of souls are lost.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Where's Giovanni?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Newly walked abroad,
And (As I heard him say) gone to the friar
His reverent tutor.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: That's a blessed man,
A man made up of holiness, I hope
He'll teach him how to gain another world.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Fair gentlewoman, here's a letter sent:
To you from my young cousin, I dare swear
He loves you in his soul, would you could hear
Sometimes, what I see daily, sighs and tears,
As if his breast were prison to his heart.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Receive it Annabella.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Alas good man.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: What's that she said?

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: And please you sir, she said, alas good man, truly I do commend him to her every night before her first sleep, because I would have her dream of him, and she harkens to that most religiously.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p:
Say'st so, godamercy Putana there's something for thee, and prithee do what thou canst on his behalf; sha'not
be lost labour, take my word for't.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: Thank you most heartily sir, now I have a feeling of your mind, let me alone to work.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Guardian!

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: Did you call?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Keep this letter,

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Signior Florio, in any case bid her read it instantly.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Keep it for what? pray read it me here right.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: I shall sir,

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: How d'ye find her inclined signior

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Troth sir I know not how; not all so well
As I could wish.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Sir I am bound to rest your cousin's debtor,
The jewel I'll return, for if he love,
I'll count that love a jewel.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Mark you that?
Nay keep them both sweet maid.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: You must excuse me,
Indeed I will not keep it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Where's the ring,
That which your mother in her will bequeathed,
And charged you on her blessing not to give't
To any but your husband? send back that.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: I have it not,

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ha I have it not, where is't?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: My brother in the morning took it from me,
Said he would wear't today.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Well, what do you say
To young Bergetto's love? are you content
To match with him? speak.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: There's the point indeed.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: What shall I do, I must say something now.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What say, why d'ye not speak?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Sir with your leave
Please you to give me freedom.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yes you have.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Signior Donado, if your nephew mean
to raise his better fortunes in his match,
The hope of me will hinder such a hope;
Sir if you love him, as I know you do;
Find one more worthy of his choice then me,
In short, I'm sure, I sha'not be his wife.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Why here's plain dealing, I commend thee for't,
And all the worst I wish thee, is heaven bless thee,
Your father yet and I will still be friends,
Shall we not signior Florio?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yes, why not?
Look here your cousin comes.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: O coxcomb, what doth he make here?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Where's my uncle sirs.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: What's the news now?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Save you uncle save you, you must not think I come for nothing masters, and how and how is't? what you have read my letter, ah, there I — tickled you i'faith.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: But 'twere better you had tickled her in another place.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Sirrah sweetheart, I'll tell thee a good jest, and riddle what 'tis.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: You say you'd tell me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: As I was walking just now in the street, I met a swaggering fellow would needs take the wall of me, and because he did thrust me, I very valiantly called him rogue, he hereupon bade me draw, I told him I had more wit than so, but when he saw that I would not, he did so maul me with the hilts of his rapier, that my head sung whilst my fear capered in the kennel.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Was ever the like ass seen?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: And what did you all this while?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Laugh at him for a gull, till I see the blood run about mine ears, and then I could not choose but find in my heart to cry; till a fellow with a broad beard; (They say he is a new-come doctor) called me into this house, and gave me a plaster, look you here 'tis; and sir there was a young wench washed my face and hands most excellently, i'faith I shall love
her as long as I live for't, did she not Poggio?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Yes and kissed him too.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Why la now, you think I tell a lie uncle I warrant.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Would he that beat thy blood out of thy head, had beaten some wit into it; for I fear thou never wilt have any.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: O uncle, but there was a wench, would have done a man's heart good to have looked on her, by this light she had a face methinks worth twenty of you mistress Annabella.

sp.speaker: Do,
sp.p: Was ever such a fool born?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: I am glad she liked you sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Are you so, by my troth I thank you forsooth.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Sure 'twas the doctor's niece, that was last day with us here:

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: 'Twas she, 'twas she.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: How do you know that simplicity?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Why does not he say so? if I should have said no, I should have given him the lie uncle, and so have deserved a dry beating again; I'll none of that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: A very modest well-behaved young maid as I have seen.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Is she indeed?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Indeed she is, if I have any judgement.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Well sir, now you are free, you need not care for sending letters, now you are dismissed, your mistress here will none of you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: No; why what care I for that, I can have wenches enough in Parma for half a crown a piece, cannot I Poggio?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: I'll warrant you sir.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Signior Florio, I thank you for your free recourse you gave for my admittance; and to you fair maid that jewel I will give you 'gainst your marriage, come will you go sir?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I marry will I mistress, farewell mistress, I'll come again tomorrow — farewell mistress.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Son, where have you been? what alone, alone, still, still? I would not have it so, you must forsake this over bookish humour. Well, your sister hath shaken the fool off.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: 'Twas no match for her.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Twas not indeed I meant it nothing less,
Soranzo is the man I only like;
Look on him Annabella, come, 'tis suppertime,
And it grows late.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Whose jewel's that?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Some sweethearts.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: So I think.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: A lusty youth, signior Donado gave it me
To wear against my marriage.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: But you shall not wear it, send it him back again.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: What, you are jealous?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: That you shall know anon, at better leisure:
Welcome sweet night, the evening crowns the day.

div.head: Actus tertius.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Does my uncle think to make me a baby still? no,
Poggio, he shall know, I have a sconce now.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: I let him not bob you off like an ape with an apple.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, I will have the wench, if he were ten uncles, in despite of his nose Poggio.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Hold him to the grindstone, and give not a jot of ground, she hath in a manner promised you already.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: True Poggio, and her uncle the doctor
Swore I should marry her.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: He swore I remember.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: And I will have her that's more; didst see the codpiece-point she gave me, and the box of marmalade?

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Very well, and kissed you, that my chops watered at the sight on't; there's no way but to clap up a marriage in hugger-mugger .

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
I will do't for I tell thee Poggio, I begin to grow valiant
methinks, and my courage begins to rise.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Should you be afraid of your uncle?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Hang him old doting rascal, no, I say I will have her.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.p: Lose no time then.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I will beget a race of wise men and constables, that shall cart whores at their own charges, and break the Duke's peace ere I have done myself. — come away.

div.stage: Enter Florio, Giovanni, Soranzo, Annabella, Putana and Vasques.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My lord Soranzo, though I must confess,
The proffers that are made me, have been great
In marriage of my daughter; yet the hope
Of your still rising honours, have prevailed
Above all other jointures; here she is,
She knows my mind, speak for yourself to her,
And hear you daughter, see you use him nobly,
For any private speech, I'll give you time:
Come son and you, the rest let them alone,
Agree as they may.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Sister be not all woman, think on me.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: Vasques?

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: Attend me without —

div.stage: Exeunt omnes, manet Soran. And Anna.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Sir what's your will with me?

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: Do you not know what I should tell you?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Yes, you'll say you love me.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: And I'll swear it too; will you believe it?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: 'Tis not point of faith.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: Have you not will to love?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Not you.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: Whom then?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: That's as the fates infer.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Of those I'm regent now.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: What mean you sweet?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: To live and die a maid.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: O that's unfit.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Here's one can say that's but a woman's note.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: Did you but see my heart, then would you swear —

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: That you were dead.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: That's true, or somewhat near it.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: See you these true love's tears?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Now she winks.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: They plead to you for grace.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Yet nothing speak.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: O grant my suit.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: What is't

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: To let me live.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Take it —.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: Still yours. —

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: That is not mine to give.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: One such another word would kill his hopes.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.p: Mistress, to leave those fruitless strifes of wit, I know I have loved you long, and loved you truly; not hope of what you have, but what you are have drawn me on, then let me not in vain still feel the rigour of your chaste disdain. I'm sick, and sick to th'heart.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Help, aquavitae

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.p: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: Why I thought you had been sick.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.p: Do you mock my love?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: There sir she was too nimble.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.p: 'Tis plain; she laughs at me, these scornful taunts neither become your modesty, or years.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: You are no lookingglass, or if you were, I'd dress my language by you.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: I'm confirmed —

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.p: To put you out of doubt, my lord, methinks your common sense should make you understand, that if I loved you, or desired your love, some way I should have given you better taste: but since you are a noble man, and one I would not wish should spend his youth in hopes, let me advise you here, to forbear your suit, and think I wish you well, I tell you this.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: Is't you speak this?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Yes, I myself; yet know
Thus far I give you comfort, if mine eyes
Could have picked out a man (Amongst all those
That sued to me) to make a husband of,
You should have been that man; let this suffice,
Be noble in your secrecy and wise.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Why now I see she loves me.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: One word more:
As ever virtue lived within your mind,
As ever noble courses were your guide.
As ever you would have me know you loved me,
Let not my father know hereof by you:
If I hereafter find that I must marry,
It shall be you or none.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: I take that promise.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: O, o my head.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: What's the matter, not well?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: O I begin to sicken.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Heaven forbid.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: Help, help, within there ho.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Look to your daughter signior Florio.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Hold her up, she swoons.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Sister how d'ye?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Sick, brother, are you there?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Convey her to her bed instantly, whilst I send for a physician, quickly I say.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Alas poor child.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: O Vasques, now I doubly am undone.
Both in my present and my future hopes:
She plainly told me, that she could not love,
And thereupon soon sickened, and I fear
Her life's in danger.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.p: By'r lady sir, and so is yours, if you knew all. — alas sir, I am sorry for that, may be 'tis but the maids sickness, an overflux of youth, and then sir, there is no such present remedy, as present marriage. But hath she given you an absolute denial?

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: She hath, and she hath not; I'm full of grief,
But what she said, I'll tell thee as we go.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: O sir, we are all undone, quite undone, utterly undone,
And shamed forever; your sister, o your sister.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: What of her? for heaven's sake speak, how does she?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: O that ever I was born to see this day.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: She is not dead, ha, is she?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Dead? no, she is quick, 'tis worse, she is with child,
You know what you have done; heaven forgive 'ee,
'Tis too late to repent, now heaven help us.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: With child? how dost thou know't?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: How do I know't? am I at these years ignorant, what the meaning's of quames, and waterpangs be? of changing of colours, queasiness of stomachs, pukings, and another thing that I could name; do not (For her and your credit's sake) spend the time in asking how, and which way, 'tis so; she is quick upon my word, if you let a physician see her water you're undone.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: But in what case is she?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.p: Prettily amended, 'twas but a fit which I soon espied, and she must look for often henceforward.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Commend me to her, bid her take no care,
Let not the doctor visit her I charge you,
Make some excuse, till I return; o me,
I have a world of business in my head,
Do not discomfort her; how do this news perplex me!
If my father come to her, tell him she's recovered well,
Say 'twas but some ill diet; d'ye hear woman,
Look you to't.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: And how d'ye find her sir.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Indifferent well,
I see no danger, scarce perceive she's sick,
But that she told me, she had lately eaten
Mellowness, and as she thought, those disagreed
With her young stomach.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Did you give her ought?

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: An easy surfeit water, nothing else,
You need not doubt her health; I rather think
Her sickness is a fullness of her blood,
You understand me?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I do; you counsel well,
And once within these few days, will so order't
She shall be married, ere she know the time.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Yet let not haste (Sir) make unworthy choice,
That were dishonour.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Master doctor no,
I will not do so neither, in plain words
My lord Soranzo is the man I mean.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: A noble and a virtuous gentleman.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: As any is in Parma; not far hence,
Dwells father Bonaventure, a grave friar,
Once tutor to my son; now at his cell
I'll have 'em married.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: You have plotted wisely.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I'll send one straight
To speak with him tonight .

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Soranzo's wise, he will delay no time.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: It shall be so.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Good peace be here and love.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Welcome religious friar, you are one,
That still bring blessing to the place you come to.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Sir, with what speed I could, I did my best,
To draw this holy man from forth his cell,
To visit my sick sister, that with words
of ghostly comfort in this time of need,
He might absolve her, whether she live or die.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Twas well done Giovanni, thou herein
Hast showed a Christians' care, a brother's love
Come father, I'll conduct you to her chamber,
And one thing would entreat you.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Say on sir.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I have a father's dear impression,
And wish before I fall into my grave,
That I might see her married, as 'tis fit;
A word from you grave man, will win her more,
Than all our best persuasions.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Gentle sir,
All this I'll say, that heaven may prosper her.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Now if the doctor keep his word, Soranzo,
Twenty to one you miss your bride; I know
'Tis an unnoble act, and not becomes
A soldier's valour; but in terms of love,
Where merit cannot sway, policy must.
I am resolved, if this physician
Play not on both hands, then Soranzo falls.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: You are come as I could wish, this very night Soranzo,
'Tis ordained must be affied to Annabella; and for ought
I know, married.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Yet your patience,
The place, 'tis friars Bonaventure's cell.
Now I would wish you to bestow this night,
In watching thereabouts, 'tis but a night,
If you miss now, tomorrow I'll know all.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Have you the poison?

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Here 'tis in this box,
Doubt nothing, this will do't; in any case
As you respect your life, be quick and sure.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: I'll speed him.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Do; away, for 'tis not safe
you should be seen much here — ever my love.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: And mine to you.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: So, if this be't, I'll laugh and hug revenge;
And they that now dream of a wedding-feast,
May chance to mourn the lusty bridegroom's ruin.
But to my other business; niece Philotis.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Uncle.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: My lovely niece, you have bethought 'ee.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Yes, and as you counselled,
Fashioned my heart to love him, but he swears
He will tonight be married; for he fears
His uncle else, if he should know the drift,
Will hinder all, and call his coz to shrift.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Tonight ? why best of all; but let me see,
I — ha — yes, — so it shall be; in disguise
We'll early to the friars, I have thought on't.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Uncle, he comes.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Welcome my worthy coz.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I ass pretty lass, come buss lassae, a ha Poggio.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: There's hope of this yet.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: You shall have time enough, withdraw a little,
We must confer at large.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Have you not sweetmeats, or dainty devices for me?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: You shall enough sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Sweetheart, mark that Poggio; by my troth I cannot choose but kiss thee once more for that word sweetheart; Poggio, I have a monstrous swelling about my stomach, whatsoever the matter be.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: You shall have physic for't sir.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Time runs apace.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: Time's a blockhead.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Be ruled, when we have done what's fit to do,
Than you may kiss your fill, and bed her too.

div.stage: Enter the friar in his study, sitting in a chair, Annabella kneeling and whispering to him, a table before them and wax-lights, she weeps, and wrings her hands.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: I am glad to see this penance; for believe me,
You have unripped a soul, so foul and guilty.
As I must tell you true, I marvel how
The earth hath born you up, but weep, weep on,
These tears may do you good; weep faster yet,
Whiles I do read a lecture.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Wretched creature.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Ay, you are wretched, miserably wretched.
Almost condemned alive; there is a place
(List daughter) in a black and hollow vault,
Where day is never seen; there shines no sun,
But flaming horror of consuming fires;
A sightless sulphur, choked with smoky fogs
Of an infected darkness; in this place
Dwell many thousand, thousand sundry sorts
Of never dying deaths; there damned fowls
Roar without pity, there are gluttons fed
With toads and adders; there is burning oil
Poured down the drunkard's throat, the usurer
Is forced to sup whole draughts of molten gold;
There is the murderer forever stabbed,
Yet can he never die; there lies the wanton
On racks of burning steel, whiles in his soul
He feels the torment of his raging lust.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Mercy, o mercy.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: There stands these wretched things.
Who have dreamt out whole years in lawless sheets
And secret incests, cursing one another;
Than you will wish, each kiss your brother gave,
Had been a dagger's point; than you shall hear
How he will cry, o would my wicked sister
Had first been damned, when she did yield to lust.
But soft, methinks I see repentance work
New motions in your heart, say? how is't with you?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Is there no way left to redeem my miseries?

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: There is, despair not; heaven is merciful,
And offers grace even now; 'tis thus agreed,
First, for your honour's safety that you marry
The lord Soranzo, next, to save your soul,
Leave off this life, and henceforth live to him.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Ay me.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Sigh not, I know the baits of sin
Are hard to leave, o 'tis a death to do't.
Remember what must come, are you content?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: I am.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: I like it well, we'll take the time,
Who's near us there?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Did you call father?

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Is lord Soranzo come?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: He plays below.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Have you acquainted him at full?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I have and he is overjoyed.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: And so are we: bid him come near.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: My sister weeping, ha? I fear this friar's falsehood,
I will call him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Daughter, are you resolved?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Father, I am.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My lord Soranzo, here
Give me your hand, for that I give you this.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: Lady, say you so too?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: I do, and vow, to live with you and yours.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: Timely resolved:
My blessing rest on both, more to be done,
You may perform it on the morning-sun.

div.stage: Enter Grimaldi with his rapier drawn, and a dark-lantern.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: 'Tis early night as yet, and yet too soon
To finish such a work; here I will lie
To listen who comes next.

div.stage: Enter Bergetto and Philotis disguised, and after Richardetto and Poggio.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: We are almost at the place, I hope sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: I hear them near, and heard one say sweetheart,
'Tis he; now guide my hand some angry justice
Home to his bosom, now have at you sir.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: O help, help, here's a stitch fallen in my guts,
O for a flesh-tailor quickly — Poggio.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: What ails my love?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.l: I am sure I cannot piss forward and backward and yet
I am wet before and behind, lights, lights, ho lights.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Alas, some villain here has slain my love.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: O heaven forbid it; raise up the next neighbours
Instantly Poggio, and bring lights,
How is't Bergetto? slain?
It cannot be; are you sure you're hurt?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: O my belly seethes like a porridge-pot, some cold water I shall boil over else; my whole body is in a sweat, that you may wring my shirt; feel here — why Poggio.

div.stage: Enter Poggio with officers, and lights and halberts.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: Here; alas, how do you?

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Give me a light, what's here? all blood! O sirs,
Signior Donado's nephew now is slain,
Follow the murderer with all the haste
Up to the city, he cannot be far hence,
Follow I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Officers.
sp.l: Follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Tear off thy linen couz, to stop his wounds,
Be of good comfort man.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Is all this mine own blood? Nay then goodnight with me, Poggio. commend me to my uncle, dost hear? bid him for my sake make much of this wench, o — I am going the wrong way sure, my belly aches so — o farewell, Poggio — o — o —

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O he is dead.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: How! dead!

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: He's dead indeed,
'Tis now too late to weep, let's have him home,
And with what speed we may, find out the murderer.

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: O my master, my master, my master.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Betrothed?

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.l: I saw it.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: And when's the marriage-day?

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.l: Some two days hence.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Two days? Why man I would but wish two hours
To send him to his last, and lasting sleep.
And Vasques thou shalt see, I'll do it bravely.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.l: I do not doubt your wisdom, nor (I trust) you my secrecy,
I am infinitely yours.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I will be thine in spite of my disgrace,
So soon? O wicked man, I durst be sworn,
He'd laugh to see me weep.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.l: And that's a villainous fault in him.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: No, let him laugh, I'm armed in my resolves
Be thou still true.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.l: I should get little by treachery against so hopeful a preferment,
As I am like to climb to.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Even to my bosom Vasques, let my youth
Revel in these new pleasures, if we thrive,
He now hath but a pair of days to live.

div.stage: Enter Florio, Donado, Richardetto, Poggio and officers.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis bootless now to show yourself a child
signior Donado, what is done, is done;
Spend not the time in tears, but seek for justice.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: I must confess, somewhat I was in fault,
That had not first acquainted you what love
Passed twixt him and my niece, but as I live,
His fortune grieves me as it were mine own.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Alas poor creature, he meant no man harm,
That I am sure of.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I believe that too;
But stay my masters, are you sure you saw
The murderer pass here?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: And it please you sir, we are sure we saw a ruffian
With a naked weapon in his hand all bloody, get into my lord
Cardinal's graces gate, that we are sure of; but for fear of his
Grace (Bless us) we durst go no further.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Know you what manner of man he was?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Yes sure I know the man, they say 'a is a soldier, he
That loved your daughter sir an't please ye, 'twas he for certain.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Grimaldi on my life.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Ay, ay, the same.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: The Cardinal is noble, he no doubt
Will give true justice.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Knock some one at the gate,

sp.speaker: Pog.
sp.l: I'll knock sir.
Servant within. What would'ee?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: We require speech with the lord Cardinal
About some present business, pray inform
His grace, that we are here.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Why how now friends? what saucy mates are you
That know nor duty nor civility?
Are we a person fit to be your host?
Or is our house become your common inn
To beat our doors at pleasure? what such haste
Is yours as that it cannot wait fit times?
Are you the masters of this commonwealth
And know no more discretion? o your news
Is here before you, you have lost a nephew
Donado, last night by Grimaldi slain:
Is that your business? well sir, we have knowledge on't.
Let that suffice.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: In presence of your grace,
In thought I never meant Bergetto harm,
But Florio you can tell, with how much scorn
Soranzo backed with his confederates,
Hath often wronged me; I to be revenged,
(For that I could not win him else to fight)
Had thought by way of ambush to have killed him,
But was unluckily, therein mistook;
Else he had felt what late Bergetto did:
And though my fault to him were merely chance,
Yet humbly I submit me to your grace,
To do with me as you please.

sp.speaker: Cardinal
sp.l: Rise up Grimaldi,
You citizens of Parma, if you seek
For justice; know as nuntio from the Pope,
For this offence I here receive Grimaldi
Into his holiness' protection.
He is no common man, but nobly born;
Of prince's blood, though you sir Florio,
Thought him to mean a husband for your daughter
If more you seek for, you must go to Rome,
For he shall thither; learn more wit for shame.
Bury your dead — away Grimaldi — leave 'em.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Is this a churchman's voice? dwells justice here?
Flo justice is fled to heaven and comes no nearer
Soranzo, was't for him? O impudence!
Had he the face to speak it, and not blush?
Come, come Donado, there's no help in this,
When Cardinals think murder's not amiss,
Great men may do there wills, we must obey,
But heaven will judge them for't another day.

div.head: Actus quartus.
div.stage: Enter the friar, Giovanni, Annabella, Philotis, Soranz, Donado, Florio, Richardetto, Putana and Vasques.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.l: These holy rights performed, now take your times,
To spend the remnant of the day in feast;
Such fit repasts are pleasing to the saints
Who are your guests, though not with mortal eyes
To be beheld; long prosper in this day
You happy couple, to each others joy:

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: Father, your prayer is heard, the hand of goodness
Hath been a shield for me against my death;
And more to bless me, hath enriched my life
With this most precious jewel; such a prize
As earth hath not another like to this.
Cheer up my love, and gentlemen, my friends,
Rejoice with me in mirth, this day we'll crown
With lusty cups to Annabella's health.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: O torture, were the marriage yet undone,
Ere I'd endure this sight, to see my love
Clipped by another, I would dare confusion,
And stand the horror of ten thousand deaths.

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.l: Are you not well sir?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Prithee fellow wait,
I need not thy officious diligence.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Signior Donado, come you must forget
Your late mishaps, and drown your cares in wine.
So an. Vasques?

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: Reach me that weighty bowl,
Here brother Giovanni, here's to you,
your turn comes next, though now a bachelor,
Here's to your sister's happiness and mine.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I cannot drink.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: 'Twill indeed offend me

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Pray, do not urge him if he be not willing.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How now, what noise is this?

sp.speaker: Vas.
sp.p: O sir, I had forgotten to tell you; certain young maidens of Parma in honour to madam Annabella's marriage, have sent their loves to her in a masque, for which they humbly crave your patience and silence.

sp.speaker: Soran.
sp.p: We are much bound to them, so much the more as it comes unexpected; guide them in.
